file_name: Chen 等 - 2020 - System integration of terrestrial mobile communication and satellite communication —the trends, chal.pdf

structured_info.title_cn: 地面移动通信与卫星通信的系统集成：B5G和6G中的趋势、挑战与关键技术
structured_info.title_en: System Integration of Terrestrial Mobile Communication and Satellite Communication: The Trends, Challenges and Key Technologies in B5G and 6G
structured_info.abstract: Mobile communication standards have been developed into a new era of B5G and 6G. In recent years, low earth orbit (LEO) satellites and space Internet have become hot topics. The integrated satellite and terrestrial systems have been widely discussed by industries and academics, and even are expected to be applied in those huge constellations in construction. This paper points out the trends of two stages towards system integration of the terrestrial mobile communication and the satellite communications: to be compatible with 5G, and to be integrated within 6G. Based on analysis of the challenges of both stages, key technologies are thereafter analyzed in detail, covering both air interface currently discussed in 3GPP for B5G and also novel network architecture and related transmission technologies toward future 6G.
structured_info.methodology: Comparative analysis of satellite communication standards (e.g., DVB-S2X vs. 5G), technical challenge decomposition, and systematic proposal of key technologies for two-stage evolution. Relies on 3GPP standardization documents and prior research.
structured_info.conclusion: Proposes a two-stage evolution for integration: 5G-compatible satellite systems (maximizing 5G reuse) and 6G-harmonized integration. Key technologies include waveform adaptation, Doppler compensation, mobility management, and novel network architectures. Future work requires detailed 6G system design.

analysis.Overview: Examines integration pathways for terrestrial and satellite communications across B5G (compatibility) and 6G (full integration), analyzing technical challenges and proposing solutions.
Background_and_Motivation: Historically independent evolution of terrestrial/satellite systems led to competition and commercial failures in satellite mobile services (e.g., Iridium).
Terrestrial systems cover only ~20% of land (6% Earth); satellites offer global coverage but face latency/distance challenges. Integration enables seamless global service.
Urgency driven by LEO constellation deployments (Starlink, OneWeb) and 5G/6G standardization efforts requiring unified approaches.
Specific integration problem addresses broader challenge of ubiquitous connectivity, disaster resilience, and next-generation mobile network requirements.
Contributes to telecommunications, satellite engineering, and wireless network architecture.
Conceptual_Framework_and_Innovations: Two-stage evolution: (1) 5G compatibility (reuse 5G tech), (2) 6G integration (harmonious terrestrial-satellite network)
Non-Terrestrial Networks (NTN): Unified framework for satellite-terrestrial standards
Assumes economic viability of LEO constellations, feasibility of 5G tech adaptation, and 6G's need for native satellite integration
Provides a structured evolutionary roadmap and taxonomy of key technologies, advancing standardization discourse.
Methodology: Comparative analysis (DVB-S2X vs. 5G), challenge decomposition (propagation, mobility, distance), technology proposals (waveform, Doppler compensation, mobility schemes)
Novelty in phased integration framework; applicability demonstrated through 3GPP NTN standardization progress
Data from 3GPP/ITU standards, prior research; representative of industry/academic consensus but lacks empirical validation
No experimental design; relies on technical rationale and standardization benchmarks
Follows telecommunications engineering paradigm, prioritizing practical deployability and backward compatibility
Results: Identified 5G limitations for satellites (e.g., Doppler shift up to 720kHz at 30GHz vs. terrestrial <1kHz)
Proposed key technologies: configurable air interface, ephemeris-assisted synchronization, earth-fixed tracking areas, regenerative satellites with ISL
Results are foundational for 3GPP NTN standards; reliability inferred from standardization adoption
Argumentation_and_Logic: Premise: Integration solves coverage/commercial gaps → Two-stage evolution → Stage-specific challenges → Technology solutions → 6G vision
Key steps: Historical analysis → Standardization gaps → Technical comparisons → Phased solutions
Strengths: Clear phased approach; addresses rebuttals (e.g., DVB-S2X limitations). Weakness: Limited quantitative validation of proposals
Strengths_and_Limitations: Comprehensive integration roadmap; actionable insights for 3GPP/ITU standardization
Limited technical depth on solutions; conceptual 6G architecture lacks implementation details
Standardization focus prioritizes incremental innovation over radical architectural shifts
Academic_Discourse_and_Rhetoric: Positions as authoritative roadmap for industry standards, citing 3GPP/ITU documents extensively
Technical terminology (e.g., bent-pipe vs. regenerative satellites); persuasive tone advocating integration inevitability
Builds authority via first-author expertise (IEEE Fellow) and institutional affiliation (State Key Lab); citations establish alignment with industry priorities
Conclusions_and_Implications: 5G compatibility maximizes reuse (e.g., NR-NTN); 6G requires holistic integration across standards, spectrum, and network layers
Future work: Dynamic routing for ISLs, on-demand core network function deployment, multi-layer resource optimization, and experimental validation
